title: Why do music companies keep putting music on CDs when downloading and streaming are the in thing? Are the artists still concerned about getting their music ripped off? If so, what is the answer? - Quora

response.answer_text: The reason why companies keep releasing CDs is simple — people like me buy them. Once we don’t, or not enough of us do, then CDs will go the way of the 8-track. But not until then. CDs are great, the best portable music format in existence. They are high-quality, easy to transport, and damage-resistant. Vinyl is great, but it’s finicky and you can’t play it in your car. Best reserved for the home stereo. Cassettes tend to crimp, break, or melt. 8-Tracks have always sucked. But what about MP3s? Yeah, you can load them up on a player and listen through your ear buds, but what goes into your ears is crap. In order to get as much music onto those devices as can go on them, they have to cut out a good chunk of the music. You won’t notice with the ear buds, but you will if you’re playing through decent speakers. You can use lossless conversion like FLAC, but FLAC players are a bit of a pain in the ass. I know because I have one. Sometimes I’ll load up the FLAC player and take it along in the truck with me, but usually that’s just for road trips. Otherwise, it’s easier for me to pick out some CDs, pop them in my carry case, and listen to them instead. Streaming isn’t always convenient, and again you get into problems with stripped-down files that just don’t sound that good. Also, when I buy a CD, I own it. I’m not leasing it. I can do whatever I want with it, including ripping it to my FLAC player. And the more folks dump their old CDs on the used market, the more opportunity I have to snap it up at a deep discount and add it to my collection for listening directly from the CD or, if I choose, the digital version I’m going to rip as soon as I’ve listened to the disc to make sure there are no errors. Other formats, excepting vinyl and reel-to-reel, aren’t as good as CDs for listening through a good system, and those formats are high-maintenance and non-portable (unless you’re taking some of your LPs over to someone else’s place where there’s a turntable). So it’s CDs for me until they stop making them.

Think you summed it up with this ‘in thing’. If you have a CD or vinyl if you look after it, it can last a lifetime and you have a collection that you can be proud of and show people. Digital media has no permanency, who knows if mp3 will still be a thing in 20 years, who knows if Spotify will even be around in 5 years. Songs get removed from these services all the time. If you want a tangible record of your music that you can convert into any format you want and store any way you want. CD is the best thing. Artists and record companies will release Cds as long as their is a market. C'mon even cassettes sales rose last year. People still want them. I use Spotify all the time but I can't tell you easily what albums I downloaded in 2014 but if I look on my shelf i can tell you which ones I bought. If I really like an act or an album I will still buy it, streaming is not a commitment or reward for them.
